ï»¿Execution Version , 215 Dated ( , 2015 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Inrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is er tered into onl(I Aigd4 2015 between: (1) MUNCHENER RUCKVERSICHERUNGS-GESELLSCHAFT, herein represented by the He il: Reinsurance Development Civision, and headquartered at K6niginstr. 107, 80802 Munchen Germany ("MUNICHRE"); ard (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMI: 1l" ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, US/ . t i INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvani i Avenue, NW, Washington, CC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("AllGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC :,. 13, USA (the "World Bank Grot:p") (each a "Party" and together the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Intern it cl al Organizations (IOs), the G7-, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investing i i Ie infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to E :11 id access to basic services anLJ raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic 1ir:, th targets. (B) Meeting this need present:; a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on e :i01 ig sources of infrastructure finnce-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coorc r al Ad effort is needed to mobilize Frivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robist pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects and :ii! is understood to be the greateE t barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investme 'I (D) Governments, development "inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an inte rs in developing the market for p ivate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand Ec e, in the numbers of structurally s)und and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual eme g an :e of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range of :1 ; te investors that actively participate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will :,r fit from collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowle:I1IE to find solutions to complex nfrastructure financing challenges that no single institution (c Id achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure IE ci ty Partnership Program ("GIF" . The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leveragil 11 ie efforts of the wide range of nstitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructu = v th the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prepE ati n, structuring, and risk mitigaton for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, tI , IF aims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supported :) ie Parties and other prospectiv ? GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepar a w II- structured, infrastructure projects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for accessi Ie expertise of the Parties anc other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from prosI E c: ie private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater le ( r; ge of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular fa 31 ge and complex projects with the potential to attract significant private capital. 2
ï»¿Execution Version (F) The Parties are now intere,-ted in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure I c ty Partnership Program, togeth?r with other partners. Accordingly, the Parties have coma to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended :o be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set ou ii Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foindational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collab< r iti )n, they are of an indicative natLre and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and ''i h other potential partners until :he GIF is formally established. The final version of these objec li w and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to ft rther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing th 3 with a view to formally establishing the program by June 2015. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foreioing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue to collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the ioles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each category b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies applicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to project selection criteria anc coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includii c sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through thE i sE of knowledge platfor ns for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finalir!ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bank.,sS 3d in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF de;i ;il is finalized, additional collabcrative efforts are required to develop the operational details c* le GIF, at all times complerrenting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the .1 a 3d knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the I, e of coordination between the Parties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Arrangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment I t,e Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their common understanding and intention. only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose an e al obligations or liabilities on ar y Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Arrangement is valid and effective for a period of one year from n date thereof, unless superseded at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3
ï»¿Execution Version 3.3 The Parties expect ti at this document and information with respect to the collabora! e activities contemplated herei 1 will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' -espective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult with ic other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's support regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arran!ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatior (Ir other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of the Parties under their constituer t documents, international conventions and any applicable law: In witness whereof, each of the Par ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executec ii two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party as :> il e date first set forth above. 4

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION 5I ) DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the 1I:ULTIL ERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: BERTRAND BADRE MANAGING DIRECTOR AN BG CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the 31F is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure prc it ch in emerging markets and dev eloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatio , provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial , c institutional investor engagement in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pub ic-private partnerships and projects with potential for commerc a viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastruc u financing solutions that no siigle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coordii z ti: 1 resources in collaboration wi h the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of the 9 i range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagement c . d stretch from upstream suppot on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemei it. 1.3 Over the longer term, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structured infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long-t rni assets in faster growing ecor omies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opr ortunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profiles 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to coerate according to the following core principles, to be finalizec p n agreement among GIF partn 3rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities the :i draw together cc mparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly those infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to bE : practice standaris for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tech'1i al and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, multi a :E al development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greater leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the reso,irces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in th! development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF par r e are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF will :D considered Funcing Partners. (ii) Technical Partners-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funded activities and/or )rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppor instruments. (iii) Advisory Partntors-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovereign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wel as other multilatera or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure projects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparati Ir, optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, witt a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inve'-tment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programming management and use of funds, and development of operational policies and procedures; ar d hold the GIF Management U it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, witi advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The composi or >f the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propo. -: 1 comprise representatives of -unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Diretltr and Chief Financial Officer o the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilitz l( coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve ei a sounding board, providing gUidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular witi o view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be adm nistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicated Ea' I established for this purpose the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fun:, i as a coordinating body as pr!jects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then move toward technical support anc, financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead indi ,i:li, l projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partner institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmen s according to specific project requirements and the project origination processes. Composit :i f the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and goverr nE ts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection c iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the followi i, principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the GIF partner institutio!is; (ii) Alignment-projects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities e i:1 strategies; (iii) Complexity-p ojects that require multiple parties to come together to provide structuring, arra iging and financial support, and/or projects which require a ble ll : financial instrurrents; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial v a:! :y, leverage public finds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors-EJ:: as through Publi,;-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's se vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastricture investments that have global public good characteristics R1 h as climate friendly-project; that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provision if infrastructure services; and t ade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconneci v t and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppcrt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with EiE ia to complementing the resour !es and support already available from partner entities and oth :i funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following acti i E corresponding to major proje,-t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; prcject definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scre !r ir 1; and legal, regulatory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparation and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and P P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrang ng and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financing packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-including in particular the management of environmental and s:i.i; impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastruit ir projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supportec operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements fc r external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards and :t standards and policies, and develop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GIF Technical Partners who are oxpected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities. 9

The opentional details for the GIF will at all times complement the e :i t g efforts and facilities of these MDB!3, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure I r:j: ot preparation resources and initiatives :isted below: a. African Development Bank (AfDB) - NEPAD Infrastructure Project Preparation Fa ty (NEPAD-IPPF) as v ell as the project development business segment of AfricaE) E d various support effor::s for Africa-focused PPFs; b. Asian Developmer Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its pro:d A Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated nu it o al PPFs; c. European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Tra 1 fin Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('IP " d. European Investment Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facilit f. Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure Te( hi al Assistance Facility (4FFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Corplr lt )n (IFC); and g. World Bank Group (WBG) comprising the International Bank for Reconstructic n1 i id Development (IBRD , the International Development Association (IDA), the Intern i c al Finance Corporation (IFC), and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIC ). 10
